SYNDROME: Anorexia; darkening; skin ulcers; abdominal distension; splenomegaly; visceral petechiation; necrotic enteritis
Anorexia; darkening; skin ulcers; abdominal distension; splenomegaly; visceral petechiation; necrotic enteritis
Anorexia; darkening; skin ulcers; abdominal distension; splenomegaly; visceral petechiation; necrotic enteritis
Anorexia; darkening; splenomegaly; miliary lesions of spleen or spleen granulomatosis (chronic form)
Emaciation; poor growth; hypertrophic kidney and spleen with granulomas
Miliary nodules on skin or gills
Skin darkening; skin dusty appearance (velvet disease)
Skin lesions; white spot or multifocal white patches (marine white spot disease)
Skin and gill lesions; depigmentation; ulcerations; skin area haemorrhages
Skin and gill lesions; depigmentation; ulcerations; skin area haemorrhages
Skin and gill lesions; depigmentation; ulcerations; skin area haemorrhages
Reduced production; reduced growth rate; low mortality
Reduced production; reduced growth rate; low mortality
Reduced production; reduced growth rate; low mortality
Skin cloudiness; focal reddening with excess mucus production; epithelial hyperplasia; gill haemorrhages
Skin cloudiness; focal reddening with excess mucus production; epithelial hyperplasia; gill haemorrhages
Growth retardation; gills and skin tissue necrosis; adults and larvae on fish
Growth retardation; gills and skin tissue necrosis; adults and larvae on fish
Growth retardation; gills and skin tissue necrosis; adults and larvae on fish
Erratic swimming, eventually to bottom of tank where death occurs
MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; biosecurity; broodstock screening; vaccines being developed

SYNDROME: Dark skin; lethargy; distended abdomen; haemorrhages
MEASURES: Avoid use of feed with very high lipid levels; antibiotics

SYNDROME: Anorexia; focal necrosis of the gills
MEASURES: Vaccination of broodstock and juveniles; use of immunostimulant and vitamin treatments; good hygiene and disinfection of water supply; antibiotics

SYNDROME: 'Belly up' syndrome, with or without the presence of haemorrhaging
MEASURES: Effective disinfection and dry-out period for land-based fattened units; adapt feeding regime prepare fish for winter period; antibiotic treatment ineffective in vivo
Good hygiene and disinfection of water supply; antibiotics
Reduce feeding rate; reduce biomass; avoid additional stress on diseased fish; low pathogenicity - no treatment

SYNDROME: Distended abdomen; disoriented spinning motion; immobility with the head down
MEASURES: Effective UV treatment of incoming water during first larval stages

SYNDROME: Erratic swimming eventually floating upside down whilst breathing rapidly after which death occurs; eyes bulge; bleeding from base of pectoral fins, dorsal fin and vent
Whitish lesions in the kidney; bleeding from kidneys and liver; some fish may lose appetite and swim close to surface; appear dark in colour
Lethargy; reduced appetite; gasping at water surface; pale gills & heart; fluid in body cavity; dark liver; haemorrhages in internal organs
MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; biosecurity; bloodwater disinfection

SYNDROME: Lethargy; reduced appetite; gasping at water surface; pale gills & heart; fluid in body cavity; dark liver; haemorrhages in internal organs
MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; biosecurity; bloodwater disinfection

SYNDROME: Whitish lesions in the spleen & kidney; bleeding from kidney & liver
MEASURES: Statutory controls; biosecurity; broodstock screening; vaccination

SYNDROME: Whitish lesions in the spleen & kidney; bleeding from kidney & liver
MEASURES: Statutory controls; biosecurity; broodstock screening; vaccination

SYNDROME: Reduced appetite; haemorrhaging at base of fins; fluid in body cavity; enlarged spleen; intestine engorged with blood; focal lesions in muscle
Lethargy; reduced appetite; gasping at water surface; pale gills & heart; fluid in body cavity; dark liver; haemorrhages in internal organs
MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; biosecurity; bloodwater disinfection

SYNDROME: White cysts in muscle; soft flesh texture
Dark coloration; lethargy; anorexia; erratic swimming; pale gills; fluid in body cavity; swollen kidney & spleen
Reduced growth; scale loss; haemorrhaging of eyes & fins
MEASURES: Paraciticides: bath Azamethiphos, Cypermethrin, hydrogen peroxide; in feed Emamectin, telflubenzuron

SYNDROME: Reduced appetite; severe anaemia; swollen spleen & soft kidney; focal muscle lesions
Erratic swimming eventually floating upside down whilst breathing rapidly after which death occurs; eyes bulge; bleeding from base of pectoral fins, dorsal fin and vent
Lethargy; reduced appetite; gasping at water surface; pale gills & heart; fluid in body cavity; dark liver; haemorrhages in internal organs
MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; biosecurity; bloodwater disinfection

SYNDROME: Inflammation of intestine; reddening of fins; boils on body; pectoral fins infected; tissues die back
MEASURES: Antibiotic mixed with food, e.g. oxytetracycline

SYNDROME: Smaller lesions on body that become open sores; fins become reddened and tissues break down
Loss of appetite; fins and areas around vent and mouth become reddened; sometimes bleeding around mouth and gills; potential high mortality
MEASURES: Same as furunculosis, plus vaccine for greater protection

SYNDROME: Loss of appetite; swelling and reddening of gills; eventually gill filaments mass together and become paler with a secretion blocking gill function in later stage
MEASURES: Bathing in bacteriocide and regular filtering of water supply to remove particles in water

SYNDROME: Erratic swimming, eventually to bottom of tank where death occurs
MEASURES: No treatment available; eradicate disease by removal of infected stock

SYNDROME: Erratic swimming eventually floating upside down whilst breathing rapidly after which death occurs; eyes bulge; bleeding from base of pectoral fins, dorsal fin and vent
Bulging eyes and, in some cases, bleeding eyes; pale gills; swollen abdomen; lethargy
White patches on body; becoming lethargic; attempt to remove parasites by rubbing on side of tank
MEASURES: Formalin bath for surface parasites; copper sulphate for parasites below surface; prevented by fast-flowing water

SYNDROME: Darkening of skin; swimming in spinning fashion; deformities around gills and tail fin; death eventually occurs
MEASURES: No treatment; fish must be kept out of infected water; water treated with calcium cyanamide

SYNDROME: Lethargic, sinking to bottom of tank where death occurs; some fish make sudden random movements
Blue-grey slime on skin which contains parasite
Parasites attached to caudal and anal fins; body and fins erode, leaving lesions that are attacked by Saprolegnia
Eye lens cloudy; loss of condition
MEASURES: No treatment available. Water supply kept clear of snail hosts

SYNDROME: Inflammation of intestine; reddening of fins; boils on body; pectoral fins infected; tissues die back
Lethargy; reduced appetite; gasping at water surface; pale gills & heart; fluid in body cavity; dark liver; haemorrhages in internal organs
MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; biosecurity; bloodwater disinfection

SYNDROME: Whitish lesions in the kidney; bleeding from kidneys and liver; some fish may lose appetite and swim close to surface; appear dark in colour
Lethargy; appetite loss; gasping at water surface; pale gills & heart; fluid in body cavity; dark liver; haemorrhages in internal organs
MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; biosecurity; bloodwater treatment

SYNDROME: Bulging eyes and, in some cases, bleeding eyes; pale gills; swollen abdomen; lethargy
MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; vaccines being developed

SYNDROME: Erratic swimming, eventually to bottom of tank where death occurs
MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; biosecurity; broodstock screening; vaccines being developed

SYNDROME: Inflammation of intestine; reddening of fins; boils on body; pectoral fins infected; tissues die back
Whitish lesions in the kidney; bleeding from kidneys and liver; some fish may lose appetite and swim close to surface; appear dark in colour
Black, lethargic fish 'hanging' in areas of low flow; bilateral exophthalmia; abdominal distension as result of fluid accumulation; haemorrhages of mouth and gills
Increased mortality; anorexia; pale gills and lowered haematocrits; swollen abdomens; affected fish appear dark and lethargic, swimming at the sides of enclosures
White or grey patches of filamentous threads on surface; cotton-like appearance radiating in circular, crescent-shaped or whorled pattern; usually begins on head or fins
Reduced growth; loss of scales; haemorrhaging of eyes and fins
MEASURES: Paraciticides (bath e.g. Azamethiphos, Cypermethrin, Hydrogen peroxide); in feed (e.g. Emamectin, teflubenzuron)

SYNDROME: Reduced growth; loss of scales; haemorrhaging of eyes and fins
MEASURES: Paraciticides (bath e.g. Azamethiphos, Cypermethrin, Hydrogen peroxide); in feed (e.g. Emamectin, teflubenzuron)

SYNDROME: Reduced growth; loss of scales; haemorrhaging of eyes and fins
MEASURES: Paraciticides (bath e.g. Azamethiphos, Cypermethrin, Hydrogen peroxide); in feed (e.g. Emamectin, teflubenzuron)

SYNDROME: Reduced growth; reduced condition factor; aesthetically unacceptable to consumers
MEASURES: Fenbendazole/praziquantel in feed for Eubothrium; avoidance of early hosts

SYNDROME: Reduced growth; reduced condition factor; aesthetically unacceptable to consumers
MEASURES: Fenbendazole/praziquantel in feed for Eubothrium; avoidance of early hosts

SYNDROME: Irritation response; heavy and laboured operculum movements; flashing and rubbing; skin cloudiness caused by excess mucus; focal redness; lethargy
Irritation response; heavy and laboured operculum movements; flashing and rubbing; skin cloudiness caused by excess mucus; focal redness; lethargy
Irritation response; heavy and laboured operculum movements; flashing and rubbing; skin cloudiness caused by excess mucus; focal redness; lethargy

Source: Garseth ÅH, Fritsvold C, Svendsen JC, Jensen BB, Mikalsen AB. Cardiomyopathy syndrome in Atlantic salmon Salmo salar L.: A review of the current state of knowledge. J Fish Dis. 2018;41:11–26. https://doi.org/10.1111/jfd.12735

SYNDROME: Erratic swimming eventually floating upside down whilst breathing rapidly after which death occurs; eyes bulge; bleeding from base of pectoral fins, dorsal fin and vent

Emaciated, although shows good appetite in early stage, then weakens, becomes listless, loses appetite & colour pattern darkens; fin & tail rot and skin patches/sores; faeces white & stringy/slimy; scrapes belly against bottom or may start to tremble; larval stage of parasite located in muscle tissue & can be seen through skin, appearing either coiled up or rod-like
MEASURES: Administer trichlorfon (with caution for small fish); niclosamide, levamisole or mebendazole mixed in feed

SYNDROME: Parasite visible on skin, head embedded deep in the tissues of the host; haemorrhages and open wounds at site of infection; weight loss; respiratory difficulties; sluggishness; red areas; ulcers; scale loss; fin damage; scraping and sometimes hanging vertically or belly up; parasite length 5 to 22 mm
MEASURES: KMnO4 bath or 0.8-1.1% NaCl (KMnO4 may be lethal to small fish at dosages required to kill Lernaea)

SYNDROME: Slime covers skin like fog, fins clamped and denuded of tissue
Infestation occurs commonly in the intestine

Dark coloration; increased mucus build-up; occasional appearance of skin lesions followed by scale loss; difficult or rapid breathing; reduced appetite and weight loss; secondary bacterial infections in advanced stage leading to pale and/or red skin patches and skin & fin rot
MEASURES: Treat with formaldehyde (250 ml/litre) or 10mg/litre malachite green; place infected fish in freshwater bath or treat with effective antibacterial agents

SYNDROME: Loss of appetite; lethargic swimming; excess mucus production; lumpy body surface
MEASURES: Dip infected fish in freshwater (makes transparent parasite visible); bathe in 150 ppm H2 02 for 30 minutes

SYNDROME: Erratic swimming, eventually to bottom of tank where death occurs
MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; biosecurity; broodstock screening; vaccines being developed

SYNDROME: Pale or dark colouration; erratic swimming behaviour; spiral swimming; bloating; 'fainting'; extensive vacuolation of the brain & spinal cord; generally encountered during hatchery phase
MEASURES: Screening of broodstock; low larval rearing densities; optimal larval nutrition; improved broodstock nutrition; improved hatchery hygiene

SYNDROME: Wart-like growths on skin & fins; generally only fatal if infection severe & associated with very poor environmental conditions
MEASURES: Removal of infected fish; improved environment

SYNDROME: Marine fish with darkening; lethargy; anorexia; reddened ulcerations on body; reddened abdominal fluid; associated with nursery systems, poor environment & skin trauma
Marine fish with darkening; lethargy; anorexia; reddened ulcerations on body; reddened abdominal fluid; associated with nursery systems, poor environment & skin trauma
Freshwater fish with irregular reddened skin ulcerations; lethargy; anorexia; reddened abdominal fluid; pale gills; associated with poor environment & skin trauma
Freshwater fish with irregular reddened skin ulcerations; lethargy; anorexia; reddened abdominal fluid; pale gills; associated with poor environment & skin trauma
Freshwater fish with irregular reddened skin ulcerations; lethargy; anorexia; reddened abdominal fluid; pale gills; associated with poor environment & skin trauma
Freshwater fish with irregular reddened skin ulcerations; lethargy; anorexia; reddened abdominal fluid; pale gills; associated with poor environment & skin trauma
Irregular reddened skin ulcerations; loss of scales; associated with poor environment & skin trauma
Darkened fish; anorexia; pale gills; reddened abdominal fluid; reddened abdominal organs & inner wall
Swimming at water surface; gulping; rapid opercular movement; excess mucus on gills; white patches on gills; most commonly occurs in nursery phase
MEASURES: Improve water quality; treatment with salinity reversal, potassium permanganate or quaternary ammonium baths; increase water exchange; reduce stocking density

SYNDROME: Swimming at water surface; gulping; rapid opercular movement; excess mucus on gills; white patches on gills; most commonly occurs in nursery phase
MEASURES: Improve water quality; treatment with salinity reversal, potassium permanganate or quaternary ammonium baths; increase water exchange; reduce stocking density

SYNDROME: Darkened fish; lethargy; swollen abdomen; adhesions & bad smelling fluid in abdomen; abdominal fistulas; more common in recirculation systems
Acute disease in intensive larval rearing systems; anorexia; pin heads; darkened fish & death
Swimming at water surface; rapid opercular movements; disease rare but seen in marine fish & in recirculation systems
Swimming at water surface; rapid opercula movement; flared opercula; seen in poor environmental conditions & in weakened fish
MEASURES: Treatment with salt, formalin or potassium permanganate bath or combinations

SYNDROME: Swimming at water surface; rapid opercula movement; flared opercula; seen in poor environmental conditions & in weakened fish
MEASURES: Treatment with salt, formalin or potassium permanganate bath or combinations

SYNDROME: Swimming at water surface; rapid opercular movements; excess gill mucus; typically follows cold water temperatures, high organic loads & high stocking densities
MEASURES: Increase water exchange; treatment with salt or formalin bath

SYNDROME: 'Flashing'; rubbing skin on surfaces; opaque patches on skin; raised scales; swimming at water surface; rapid opercular movements; flared opercula
MEASURES: Treatment with salinity reversal; formalin or potassium permanganate bath

SYNDROME: Found in freshwater: In young fish opaque patches or a greenish discolouration of the skin; patches of skin lifting of surface & ulcers In older fish rapid opercular movements; excess gill mucus; dark green gill colour

Found in marine conditions: In young fish opaque patches or a green discolouration of the skin; patches of skin lifting of surface & ulcersIn older fish rapid opercular movements; excess gill mucus; dark green gill colour More common in broodstock and in raceways; associated with low water temperatures or rapid drops in temperature
MEASURES: Treatment with freshwater, copper, formalin or hydrogen peroxide bath

SYNDROME: Skin ulcers in freshwater pond fish; raised fluffy surface & secondary bacterial infections
MEASURES: Reduce organic levels in water; treatment with formalin bath

SYNDROME: Rapid opercular movements; anorexia; white areas on gills
MEASURES: Treatment with salinity reversal, formalin, organo-phosphate or praziquantel bath

SYNDROME: Marine fish with opaque cornea; white patches on skin; skin ulcers; associated with high salinity & cool water temperatures
MEASURES: Treatment in freshwater or hydrogen peroxide bath

SYNDROME: Rapid opercular movements; anorexia; white areas on gills
MEASURES: Treatment with salinity reversal, formalin, organo-phosphate or praziquantel bath

SYNDROME: Marine fish with opaque cornea; white patches on skin; skin ulcers; associated with high salinity & cool water temperatures
MEASURES: Treatment in freshwater or hydrogen peroxide bath

SYNDROME: Disease uncommon but histologically spore cysts seen in gill filaments (Henneguya sp.) & brain (Kudoa sp.)
Disease uncommon but histologically spore cysts seen in gill filaments (Henneguya sp.) & brain (Kudoa sp.)
Raised lumps on skin; soft white nodules in muscle
Raised, fluffy growths on skin & fins; associated with low water temperatures & skin trauma
MEASURES: Salinity reversal and formalin baths; do not handle fish when water temperatures low

SYNDROME: Raised, fluffy growths on skin & fins; associated with low water temperatures & skin trauma
MEASURES: Salinity reversal and formalin baths; do not handle fish when water temperatures low

SYNDROME: Disc-shaped parasite visible on skin; red foci; darkening
Thin body of female parasite visible on skin with small red ulcer where parasite penetrates skin
'Flashing'; rubbing skin on surfaces; anorexia; swimming at water surface; white spots on skin & fins
MEASURES: Treatment with salinity reversal, formalin baths or combinations; treatment in copper bath for marine fish

SYNDROME: Pale skin patches on dorsal surface behind dorsal fin & on caudal peduncle; lethargy; most commonly occurs in nursery phase; in older juveniles a mouth form with erosion of skin around upper & lower jaws has been seen; associated with overstocking, tank rearing, poor hygiene & skin trauma
MEASURES: Treatment in potassium permanganate or copper baths may help in early disease; antibiotic treatment

SYNDROME: Flashing; skin darkening; lethargy; breathing difficulties; rubbing gill cover & body against rearing surfaces
Cutaneous ulcers; darkened skin; swimming behaviour alterations; bulging eyes; abdominal distension
Numerous white cysts on the skin and gills
MEASURES: Density reduction; complete disinfection of facilities

SYNDROME: Grey patches in dorsal fin area at first; lesions in head and mouth; sometimes gill rot
Haemorrhaging of fins, skin, and serosal surfaces; ulcers
Darkened skin; lethargy; frayed fins; skin ulcers; exophthalmia
Bulging eyes and, in some cases, bleeding eyes; pale gills; swollen abdomen; lethargy
MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; vaccines being developed

SYNDROME: Erratic swimming, eventually to bottom of tank where death occurs
Erratic swimming (spiralling, whirling); neuronal necrosis; swim bladder hyperinflation; darkened colour; reduced feeding
MEASURES: No known treatment; disinfection of culture systems between batches of fish (culture water - UV, ozone; materials - chlorine); culling of sick fish

SYNDROME: Spores in the mucosa of the digestive tract; inflammation of the digestive tract; discoloration; scale loss; skin ulcers
MEASURES: No known treatment; disinfection of culture systems; culling of sick fish

SYNDROME: Skin, fins & occasionally gills with enlarged white or pale red dermal fibroblasts (cauliflower-like growths)
MEASURES: No known treatment; disinfection of culture systems; quarantine fish - occasionally the fish will recover on their own; minimize stocking densities

SYNDROME: Small crustaceans attached to gills, mouth, skin; skin ulcers
MEASURES: Fresh water dip (5-15 min); formalin dip (30 min, 2-4 ml formalin in 10 litres) - not approved for food fish

SYNDROME: Swollen abdomen; skin ulcers; haemorrhages on body; protruded eyeball; lethargy; internal lesions
MEASURES: Antibacterials administered via the water or food; removal & treatment of diseased fish; disinfection of culture systems; reduce stress

SYNDROME: Skin ulcers; septicaemia; protruded eyeball; haemorrhages on body; darkened coloration
MEASURES: Antibacterials administered via water or food; removal & treatment of diseased fish; disinfection of culture system; reduce stress
Source_1: Rigos, G., Katharios, P.J.R.i.F.B., Fisheries, 2010. Pathological obstacles of newly-introduced fish species in Mediterranean mariculture: a review. 20, 47-70.

SYNDROME: Trophont (appears as small whitish spots) on skin, fins &/or gills; weakness; anorexia; flashing; scratching
MEASURES: Fresh water dip (5-15 min); tank flushing (at least 6 tank volumes per day); filtration (microscreen, drum/ bead filters); copper sulphate - not approved for food fish; formalin dips (30 min, 2-4 ml formalin in 10 litres) - not approved for food fish

SYNDROME: White dusting of the skin; respiratory distress; scratching; sloughing of skin; reduced feeding
MEASURES: Reduced salinity (≤16‰ for ~14 days, ≤10‰ for 3 hours); low temperature <19 °C; copper sulphate - not approved for food fish; formalin dip (30 min, 2-4 ml formalin in 10 litres) - not approved for food fish

Source: Rigos, G., Katharios, P.J.R.i.F.B., Fisheries, 2010. Pathological obstacles of newly-introduced fish species in Mediterranean mariculture: a review. 20, 47-70.

SYNDROME: Coughing; flashing; operculum flared out; reluctance to feed; visible on gills & fins; appears as small dark spots on gill filaments under a stereoscope
MEASURES: Copper sulphate pentahydrate; decrease salinity in some cases (freshwater dip); flush system; formalin bath/treatment; mechanical filtration down to at least 40 microns

SYNDROME: White foci visible on skin; interconnected, larger masses of whitish spots
MEASURES: Prolonged copper immersion; freshwater dips; formalin treatment; decrease salinity to 15 ‰ or less for 2 weeks; decrease system temperature to <19 ºC

SYNDROME: Reported during larval stage; white or reddish masses on the skin/fins, gill arches, or in mouth; more common in polluted waters; often associated with gram-negative bacterial condition called red sore disease
MEASURES: Formalin treatment; freshwater bath/dip; antibiotics for severe bacterial infection

SYNDROME: Reported during nursery stage; found on skin & gills; loss of appetite; lethargy; chronic low level mortality; often leads to secondary infections
MEASURES: Formalin treatment; freshwater bath; copper treatment; Praziquantel bath or prolonged immersion

SYNDROME: Reported during grow-out stage; skin damage & ulceration; eroded fins; eye lesions which can lead to blindness
MEASURES: Formalin treatment; freshwater bath; copper treatment; Praziquantel bath or prolonged immersion

SYNDROME: Poor appetite & ascites; enlarged kidney exhibiting patches or nodules; skin ulcers; spores in the digestive tract
MEASURES: No known treatment; disinfect system; quarantine affected fish

SYNDROME: Abdominal swelling; exopthalamy; cysts in liver tissue; varies with organ affected
MEASURES: Treat fish with oral monensin; reduce stress

SYNDROME: Reported during nursery stage; skin, fins & gills with white, bumpy growths
MEASURES: No known treatment; disinfect system; quarantine fish

SYNDROME: Whitish, granulomatous deposits on kidney, liver & spleen
MEASURES: None known but vaccine being developed

SYNDROME: Swollen abdomen; skin ulcers; protruded eyes; lethargy; darkening of skin; ascites in peritoneal cavity
MEASURES: Administer antibiotics; remove diseased fish; disinfect system; reduce stress

SYNDROME: Swollen abdomen; skin ulcers; protruded eyes; lethargy; darkening of skin; ascites in peritoneal cavity
MEASURES: Administer antibiotics; remove diseased fish; disinfect system; reduce stress

SYNDROME: Swollen abdomen; skin ulcers; protruded eyes; lethargy; darkening of skin; ascites in peritoneal cavity
MEASURES: Administer antibiotics; remove diseased fish; disinfect system; reduce stress

SYNDROME: Can cause blindness in cobia; protruded eyes; skin ulcers; skin darkening
MEASURES: Administer antibiotics; remove diseased fish; disinfect system; reduce stress

Source: (Liao et al. 2004) (Benetti et al. 2008) (Nhu et al. 2011).

SYNDROME: Fin erosions; haemorrhages, particularly in the head region
Moderate to extensive granuloma formation in internal organs
MEASURES: None documented. Broodstock screening (kidney biopsies); avoidance of high water temperature

SYNDROME: Moderate to extensive granuloma formation in internal organs
Itching; black spots in skin and fillets; juvenile mortality in extensive culture
MEASURES: Prophylactic measures (pen distance to shore placement; periwinkle removal or avoidance

SYNDROME: Lethargy; reduced appetite; gasping at water surface; pale gills & heart; fluid in body cavity; dark liver; haemorrhages in internal organs
MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; biosecurity; bloodwater disinfection

SYNDROME: Systemic disease; congested fins; increased mucus production; highest mortality at lower temperatures (<24 °C)

DISEASE: Red pest of eels, red sore, red boil, saltwater furunculosis
SYNDROME: Systemic infection; acute haemorrhagic and septicaemic disease with mass mortality; anorexia; darkening; abdominal distension, dermal haemorrhages; skin ulcers; occurrence of exophthalmos

MEASURES: Antibacterial drugs in feed; environmental improvement

SYNDROME: Breakdown of tissues between fin rays (fin rot)
Breakdown of tissues between fin rays (fin rot)
Systemic infection; acute haemorrhagic and septicaemic disease; haemorrhagic spots on the skin and base of fins; ulcers and skin necrosis; exophthalmia and dropsy
MEASURES: Environmental improvement; antibacterial drugs in feed

SYNDROME: Systemic infection; acute haemorrhagic and septicaemic disease; haemorrhagic spots on the skin and base of fins; ulcers and skin necrosis; exophthalmia and dropsy
MEASURES: Environmental improvement; antibacterial drugs in feed

SYNDROME: Systemic infection; acute haemorrhagic and septicaemic disease; haemorrhagic spots on the skin and base of fins; ulcers and skin necrosis; exophthalmia and dropsy
MEASURES: Environmental improvement; antibacterial drugs in feed

SYNDROME: Infestation occurs commonly in the skin

DISEASE: Epizootic ulcerativesyndrome (EUS); red spot disease (RSD); mycotic granulomatosis (MG)

SYNDROME: Fins and areas around vent and mouth become reddened; loss of appetite
Protozoan attach to gills, producing irritation, asphyxia and hypermucosis
Parasites attached to fins and gills

MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; biosecurity; broodstock screening; vaccines being developed

DISEASE: Iridovirus infection. Also known as Viral Splenic Virus (VSN)
SYNDROME: Abnormally hypertrophic cells in the spleen

DISEASE: Pancreatic-hepatic necrosis of amberjack. Also known as Yellowtail Ascite Virus (YAV)
SYNDROME: Moribund fry show anaemic gills; haemorrhaging in the liver; ascites; and petechiae in the pyloric caeca
Progressive reddening of fins and skin; skin ulceration; extensive muscular necrosis; internal haemorrhaging; reduced activity
MEASURES: Oral administration of sulfa drugs or antibiotics; limiting densities in cages; daily surveillance during feeding; keeping the fish well fed and in good condition

SYNDROME: Formation of white nodes on the internal organs (spleen, kidney); during mild outbreaks, these symptoms may not appear; can be diagnosed using commercially available diagnostic kits when suspected
MEASURES: Oral administration of antibiotics; due to high risk involved with outbreak of this disease growers used to administer prophylactic doses of medication

SYNDROME: Bleeding inside the gills; sores on the fins; ulcers on the base of the tail
MEASURES: Oral administration of antibiotics; limiting densities in cages; supplying good quality feed; avoiding over-feeding; prompt removal of infected fish

SYNDROME: Swollen lesions and ulcers on body surface; nodules sometimes present on gills
MEASURES: Control restricted to avoiding introduction of infected fish or fish products

SYNDROME: Affects circulation system and some other organs of the fish; clinical signs seen only when infection is well established, which may include change of appearance, deformity, emaciation, colour changes and loss of balance
MEASURES: No effective treatment, although a combination of oral and in-water medication with 2-phenoxyethanol has been recommended; prompt removal of infected fish; stop feeding raw fish or raw fish based products

SYNDROME: Attaches to skin; at the site of attachment fish secrete viscous fluid and develop a sore as the fish rub the site against the side of the pen; skin peels off, exposing the flesh
MEASURES: Prevented by dipping the stock in freshwater for 5 min, every 10-14 days or by dipping the stock in aerated seawater containing 500 ppm hydrogen peroxide for 5-7 min

SYNDROME: Found in the gills, which may cause a fatal anaemia
MEASURES: Cured with various drugs or by placing the fish in strong salt water (100 ‰) for 2 to 4 min

SYNDROME: Erratic swimming, eventually to bottom of tank where death occurs
MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; biosecurity; broodstock screening; vaccines being developed

SYNDROME: Erratic swimming, eventually to bottom of tank where death occurs
MEASURES: No treatment; statutory controls; biosecurity; broodstock screening; vaccines being developed

SYNDROME: Reported during nursery stage; skin, fins & gills with white, bumpy growths
MEASURES: No known treatment; disinfect system; quarantine fish
Source: Chen, X.H., Lin, K.B., Wang, X.W., 2003. Outbreaks of an iridovirus disease in maricultured large yellow croaker, Larimichthys crocea (Richardson), in China. 26, 615-619.

SYNDROME: Jian, J., Wu, Z., 2003. Effects of traditional Chinese medicine on nonspecific immunity and disease resistance of large yellow croaker, Pseudosciaena crocea (Richardson). Aquaculture. 218, 1-9.

Zuo, R., Ai, Q., Mai, K., Xu, W., Wang, J., Xu, H., Liufu, Z., Zhang, Y., 2012. Effects of dietary n-3 highly unsaturated fatty acids on growth, nonspecific immunity, expression of some immune related genes and disease resistance of large yellow croaker (Larmichthys crocea) following natural infestation of parasites (Cryptocaryon irritans). Fish & Shellfish Immunology. 32, 249-258.
